trans-unit.source: Analyze and Process JSON documents with Hive in HDInsight | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Analyze and Process JSON documents with Hive in HDInsight | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use JSON documents and analyze them using Hive in HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use JSON documents and analyze them using Hive in HDInsight.

trans-unit.source: Learn how to process and analyze JSON files using Hive in HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to process and analyze JSON files using Hive in HDInsight.

trans-unit.source: The following JSON document will be used in the tutorial
trans-unit.target: The following JSON document will be used in the tutorial

trans-unit.source: The file can be found at wasb://processjson@hditutorialdata.blob.core.windows.net/.
trans-unit.target: The file can be found at wasb://processjson@hditutorialdata.blob.core.windows.net/.

trans-unit.source: For more information on using Azure Blob storage with HDInsight, see <linkText>Use HDFS-compatible Azure Blob storage with Hadoop in HDInsight</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on using Azure Blob storage with HDInsight, see <linkText>Use HDFS-compatible Azure Blob storage with Hadoop in HDInsight</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You can copy the file to the default container of your cluster if you want.
trans-unit.target: You can copy the file to the default container of your cluster if you want.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will use the Hive console.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will use the Hive console.

trans-unit.source: For instructions of opening the Hive console, see <linkText>Use Hive with Hadoop on HDInsight with Remote Desktop</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For instructions of opening the Hive console, see <linkText>Use Hive with Hadoop on HDInsight with Remote Desktop</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The methods listed in the next section require the JSON document in a single row.
trans-unit.target: The methods listed in the next section require the JSON document in a single row.

trans-unit.source: So you must flatten the JSON document to a string.
trans-unit.target: So you must flatten the JSON document to a string.

trans-unit.source: If your JSON document is already flattened, you can skip this step and go straight to the next section on Analyzing JSON data.
trans-unit.target: If your JSON document is already flattened, you can skip this step and go straight to the next section on Analyzing JSON data.

trans-unit.source: The raw JSON file is located at wasb://processjson@hditutorialdata.blob.core.windows.net/.
trans-unit.target: The raw JSON file is located at wasb://processjson@hditutorialdata.blob.core.windows.net/.

trans-unit.source: The StudentsRaw Hive table points to the raw un-flattened JSON document.
trans-unit.target: The StudentsRaw Hive table points to the raw un-flattened JSON document.

trans-unit.source: The StudentsOneLine Hive table will store the data in the HDInsight default file system under the /json/students/ path.
trans-unit.target: The StudentsOneLine Hive table will store the data in the HDInsight default file system under the /json/students/ path.

trans-unit.source: The INSERT statement populate the StudentOneLine table with the flattened JSON data.
trans-unit.target: The INSERT statement populate the StudentOneLine table with the flattened JSON data.

trans-unit.source: The SELECT statement shall only return 1 row.
trans-unit.target: The SELECT statement shall only return 1 row.

trans-unit.source: Here is the output of the SELECT statement:
trans-unit.target: Here is the output of the SELECT statement:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Flattening of the JSON document.</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Flattening of the JSON document.</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Hive provides three different mechanisms to run queries on JSON documents:
trans-unit.target: Hive provides three different mechanisms to run queries on JSON documents:

trans-unit.source: use the GET\JSON\OBJECT UDF (User Defined Function)
trans-unit.target: use the GET\JSON\OBJECT UDF (User Defined Function)

trans-unit.source: use the JSON_TUPLE UDF
trans-unit.target: use the JSON_TUPLE UDF

trans-unit.source: use custom SerDe
trans-unit.target: use custom SerDe

trans-unit.source: write you own UDF using Python or other languages.
trans-unit.target: write you own UDF using Python or other languages.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>this article[hdinsight-python]</linkText><title></title> on running your own Python code with Hive.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>this article[hdinsight-python]</linkText><title></title> on running your own Python code with Hive.

trans-unit.source: Hive provides a built-in UDF called [get json object](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/Hive/LanguageManual+UDF#LanguageManualUDF-getjsonobject) which can perform JSON querying during run time.
trans-unit.target: Hive provides a built-in UDF called [get json object](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/Hive/LanguageManual+UDF#LanguageManualUDF-getjsonobject) which can perform JSON querying during run time.

trans-unit.source: This method takes two arguments – the table name and method name which has the flattened JSON document and the JSON field that needs to be parsed.
trans-unit.target: This method takes two arguments – the table name and method name which has the flattened JSON document and the JSON field that needs to be parsed.

trans-unit.source: Let’s look at an example to see how this UDF works.
trans-unit.target: Let’s look at an example to see how this UDF works.

trans-unit.source: Get the first name and last name for each student
trans-unit.target: Get the first name and last name for each student

trans-unit.source: Here is the output when running this query in console window.
trans-unit.target: Here is the output when running this query in console window.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>get_json_object UDF</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>get_json_object UDF</linkText>

trans-unit.source: There are a few limitations of the get-json_object UDF.
trans-unit.target: There are a few limitations of the get-json_object UDF.

trans-unit.source: Because each field in the query requires re-parsing the query, it affects the performance.
trans-unit.target: Because each field in the query requires re-parsing the query, it affects the performance.

trans-unit.source: GET\JSONOBJECT() returns the string representation of an array.
trans-unit.target: GET\JSONOBJECT() returns the string representation of an array.

trans-unit.source: To convert this to a Hive array, you will have to use regular expressions to replace the square brackets ‘[‘ and ‘]’ and then also call split to get the array.
trans-unit.target: To convert this to a Hive array, you will have to use regular expressions to replace the square brackets ‘[‘ and ‘]’ and then also call split to get the array.

trans-unit.source: This is why the Hive wiki recommends using json_tuple.
trans-unit.target: This is why the Hive wiki recommends using json_tuple.

trans-unit.source: Another UDF provided by Hive is called [jsontuple](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/Hive/LanguageManual+UDF#LanguageManualUDF-jsontuple) which performs better than [get_ json object](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/Hive/LanguageManual+UDF#LanguageManualUDF-getjson_object).
trans-unit.target: Another UDF provided by Hive is called [jsontuple](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/Hive/LanguageManual+UDF#LanguageManualUDF-jsontuple) which performs better than [get_ json object](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/Hive/LanguageManual+UDF#LanguageManualUDF-getjson_object).

trans-unit.source: This method takes a set of keys and a JSON string, and returns a tuple of values using one function.
trans-unit.target: This method takes a set of keys and a JSON string, and returns a tuple of values using one function.

trans-unit.source: The following query returns the student id and the grade from the JSON document:
trans-unit.target: The following query returns the student id and the grade from the JSON document:

trans-unit.source: The output of this script in the Hive console:
trans-unit.target: The output of this script in the Hive console:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>json_tuple UDF</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>json_tuple UDF</linkText>

trans-unit.source: JSON\TUPLE uses the [lateral view](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/Hive/LanguageManual+LateralView) syntax in Hive which allows json\tuple to create a virtual table by applying the UDT function to each row of the original table.
trans-unit.target: JSON\TUPLE uses the [lateral view](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/Hive/LanguageManual+LateralView) syntax in Hive which allows json\tuple to create a virtual table by applying the UDT function to each row of the original table.

trans-unit.source: Complex JSONs become too unwieldy because of the repeated use of LATERAL VIEW.
trans-unit.target: Complex JSONs become too unwieldy because of the repeated use of LATERAL VIEW.

trans-unit.source: Furthermore, JSON_TUPLE cannot handle nested JSONs.
trans-unit.target: Furthermore, JSON_TUPLE cannot handle nested JSONs.

trans-unit.source: SerDe is the best choice for parsing nested JSON documents, it allows you to define the JSON schema, and use the schema to parse the documents.
trans-unit.target: SerDe is the best choice for parsing nested JSON documents, it allows you to define the JSON schema, and use the schema to parse the documents.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will use one of the more popular SerDe that has been developed by <linkText>rcongiu</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will use one of the more popular SerDe that has been developed by <linkText>rcongiu</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To use the custom SerDe:
trans-unit.target: To use the custom SerDe:

trans-unit.source: Install <linkText>Java SE Development Kit 7u55 JDK 1.7.0_55</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Install <linkText>Java SE Development Kit 7u55 JDK 1.7.0_55</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Choose the Windows X64 version of the JDK if you are going to be using the Windows deployment of HDInsight
trans-unit.target: Choose the Windows X64 version of the JDK if you are going to be using the Windows deployment of HDInsight

trans-unit.source: JDK 1.8 doesn't work with this SerDe.
trans-unit.target: JDK 1.8 doesn't work with this SerDe.

trans-unit.source: After the installation is completed, add a new user environment variable:
trans-unit.target: After the installation is completed, add a new user environment variable:

trans-unit.source: Open View advanced system settings from the Windows screen.
trans-unit.target: Open View advanced system settings from the Windows screen.

trans-unit.source: Click Environment Variables.
trans-unit.target: Click Environment Variables.

trans-unit.source: Add a new JAVA_HOME environment variable is pointing to C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.7.0_55 or wherever your JDK is installed.
trans-unit.target: Add a new JAVA_HOME environment variable is pointing to C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.7.0_55 or wherever your JDK is installed.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Setting up correct config values for JDK</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Setting up correct config values for JDK</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Install <linkText>Maven 3.3.1</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: Install <linkText>Maven 3.3.1</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Add the bin folder to your path by going to Control Panel-->Edit the System Variables for your account Environment variables.
trans-unit.target: Add the bin folder to your path by going to Control Panel-->Edit the System Variables for your account Environment variables.

trans-unit.source: The screenshot below shows you how to do this.
trans-unit.target: The screenshot below shows you how to do this.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Setting up Maven</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Setting up Maven</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Clone the project from <linkText>Hive-JSON-SerDe</linkText><title></title> github site.
trans-unit.target: Clone the project from <linkText>Hive-JSON-SerDe</linkText><title></title> github site.

trans-unit.source: You can do this by clicking on the “Download Zip” button as shown in the screenshot below.
trans-unit.target: You can do this by clicking on the “Download Zip” button as shown in the screenshot below.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Cloning the project</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Cloning the project</linkText>

trans-unit.source: 4: Go to the folder where you have downloaded this package and type “mvn package”.
trans-unit.target: 4: Go to the folder where you have downloaded this package and type “mvn package”.

trans-unit.source: This should create the necessary jar files that you can then copy over to the cluster.
trans-unit.target: This should create the necessary jar files that you can then copy over to the cluster.

trans-unit.source: 5: Go to the target folder under the root folder where you downloaded the package.
trans-unit.target: 5: Go to the target folder under the root folder where you downloaded the package.

trans-unit.source: Upload the json-serde-1.1.9.9-Hive13-jar-with-dependencies.jar file to head-node of your cluster.
trans-unit.target: Upload the json-serde-1.1.9.9-Hive13-jar-with-dependencies.jar file to head-node of your cluster.

trans-unit.source: I usually put it under the hive binary folder: C:\apps\dist\hive-0.13.0.2.1.11.0-2316\bin or something similar.
trans-unit.target: I usually put it under the hive binary folder: C:\apps\dist\hive-0.13.0.2.1.11.0-2316\bin or something similar.

trans-unit.source: 6: In the hive prompt, type “add jar /path/to/json-serde-1.1.9.9-Hive13-jar-with-dependencies.jar”.
trans-unit.target: 6: In the hive prompt, type “add jar /path/to/json-serde-1.1.9.9-Hive13-jar-with-dependencies.jar”.

trans-unit.source: Since in my case, the jar is in the C:\apps\dist\hive-0.13.x\bin folder, I can directly add the jar with the name as shown below:
trans-unit.target: Since in my case, the jar is in the C:\apps\dist\hive-0.13.x\bin folder, I can directly add the jar with the name as shown below:

trans-unit.source: Now, you are ready to use the SerDe to run queries against the JSON document.
trans-unit.target: Now, you are ready to use the SerDe to run queries against the JSON document.

trans-unit.source: The following statement create a table with a defined schema
trans-unit.target: The following statement create a table with a defined schema

trans-unit.source: , StudentClassCollection array<struct< ClassId:string, ClassParticipation:string, ClassParticipationRank:string, Score:int, PerformedActivity:boolean
trans-unit.target: , StudentClassCollection array<struct< ClassId:string, ClassParticipation:string, ClassParticipationRank:string, Score:int, PerformedActivity:boolean

trans-unit.source: To list the first name and last name of the student
trans-unit.target: To list the first name and last name of the student

trans-unit.source: Here is the result from the Hive console.
trans-unit.target: Here is the result from the Hive console.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>SerDe Query 1</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>SerDe Query 1</linkText>

trans-unit.source: To calculate the sum of scores of the JSON document
trans-unit.target: To calculate the sum of scores of the JSON document

trans-unit.source: The query above uses <linkText>lateral view explode</linkText><title></title> UDF to expand the array of scores so that they can be summed.
trans-unit.target: The query above uses <linkText>lateral view explode</linkText><title></title> UDF to expand the array of scores so that they can be summed.

trans-unit.source: Here is the output from the Hive console.
trans-unit.target: Here is the output from the Hive console.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>SerDe Query 2</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>SerDe Query 2</linkText>

trans-unit.source: To find which subjects a given student has scored more than 80 points SELECT jt.StudentClassCollection.ClassId FROM json_table jt lateral view explode(jt.StudentClassCollection.Score) collection as score where score > 80;
trans-unit.target: To find which subjects a given student has scored more than 80 points SELECT jt.StudentClassCollection.ClassId FROM json_table jt lateral view explode(jt.StudentClassCollection.Score) collection as score where score > 80;

trans-unit.source: The query above returns a Hive array unlike get\json\object which returns a string.
trans-unit.target: The query above returns a Hive array unlike get\json\object which returns a string.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>SerDe Query 3</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>SerDe Query 3</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If you want to skil malformed JSON, then as explained in the <linkText>wiki page</linkText><title></title> of this SerDe you can achieve that by typing the code below:
trans-unit.target: If you want to skil malformed JSON, then as explained in the <linkText>wiki page</linkText><title></title> of this SerDe you can achieve that by typing the code below:

trans-unit.source: In conclusion, the type of JSON operator in Hive that you choose depends on your scenario.
trans-unit.target: In conclusion, the type of JSON operator in Hive that you choose depends on your scenario.

trans-unit.source: If you have a simple JSON document and you only have one field to look up on – you can choose to use the Hive UDF get\json\object.
trans-unit.target: If you have a simple JSON document and you only have one field to look up on – you can choose to use the Hive UDF get\json\object.

trans-unit.source: If you have more than one keys to look up on then you can use json_tuple.
trans-unit.target: If you have more than one keys to look up on then you can use json_tuple.

trans-unit.source: If you have a nested document, then you should use the JSON SerDe.
trans-unit.target: If you have a nested document, then you should use the JSON SerDe.
